title: “Who hath believed our report?”
html:
Isaiah begins by challenging the skeptics who refuse to believe that the literal Son of God would descend to a life of mortality. There are two main groups of skeptics: ancient Israelites and modern scholars. Although prophets had foretold the Messiah’s coming for hundreds of years, many Jews of Jesus’ time could not recognize Jesus of Nazareth as the embodiment of these Messianic prophecies. Now, centuries later, some Jewish and Christian scholars believe that Isaiah’s great messianic hymn refers to the house of Israel and not the Savior. Joseph Fielding Smith refutes this interpretation, stating:

Now Bible commentators will tell you that [Isaiah 53] has nothing to do with the life of Jesus Christ. To them this story is one concerning suffering Israel. I want to tell you that it is a story, a synopsis of the life of our Redeemer, revealed to Isaiah 700 years before the Lord was born. If you have the proper discernment you will discover this.

Although Isaiah’s prophecy that a great Redeemer would come to save humankind from sin was fulfilled, many still fail to recognize Jesus as the Messiah portrayed in this prophetic servant song.

In verse 1, Isaiah asks two hypothetical questions that challenge first our convictions and then our commitments. When he asks, “Who hath believed our report?” we question ourselves by asking, “Do I believe Isaiah’s account?” By prompting us to contemplate our beliefs about the Savior, Isaiah prepares us for the powerful truths in the following verses. The second question examines our behavior. Isaiah asks, “To whom is the arm of the Lord revealed?” or in other words, who is the described person who receives the Lord’s saving power? The answer is those whose righteous actions show that they have partaken of Christ’s atoning sacrifice.

Isaiah and other prophets use imagery of the “arm” to symbolize the Lord’s immense power and authority. Ezekiel portrays the Lord’s commanding power, writing, “with a stretched out arm, and with fury poured out, will [the Lord God] rule over you” (Ezekiel 20:33). Jeremiah rejoices in the Lord’s creative abilities, saying, “Ah Lord God! behold, thou hast made the heaven and the earth by thy great power and stretched out arm, and there is nothing too hard for thee” (Jeremiah 32:17). Nephi prophesies of the Lord’s mercy, teaching, “I will be merciful unto them, saith the Lord God, if they will repent and come unto me; for mine arm is lengthened out all the day long” (2 Nephi 28:32). Joseph Smith describes the Lord’s might, visualizing His arm “fall upon the nations” at His Second Coming (D&C 45:47). Thus, the image of the Lord’s arm portrays the full range of divine powers—from creative to destructive and from painful justice to joyful mercy.
